According to this theorem, any rational root \(\pm p/q\) must satisfy certain conditions—specifically, \(p\) must be a divisor of the constant term (\(-14\)), and \(q\) must be a divisor of the leading coefficient (\(1\)). Here, \(q\) cannot provide additional restrictions besides being equal to \(\pm1\). Thus, every rational root must actually be an integer and specifically either a divisor of \(14\) or \(-14\). direct_answer.text:
To find the integer roots of the polynomial \[x^4 + 5x^3 + 9x^2 - x - 14 = 0,\]we apply the Rational Root Theorem. According to this theorem, since the leading coefficient is \(1\) and the constant term is \(-14\), any rational root \(\pm p/q\) must satisfy \(p\) being a factor of \(-14\) and \(q\) being a factor of \(1\). Thus, potential integral roots are among \[\pm 1, \pm 2, \pm 7, \pm 14.\]We use synthetic division to check each possibility:

Testing \(x=-1\):  
\[\begin{array}{c|ccccc}
& 1 & 5 & 9 & -1 & -14 \\
\hline

1.subquestion: By Rational Root Theorem, which integers must divide any rational root?

subanswer.text: Any rational root must have a numerator that divides -14 (the constant term), and a denominator that divides 1 (the leading coefficient). Therefore, potential rational roots include factors of \(\pm1,\pm2,\pm7,\pm14\). The possible values are \(...\) listed earlier. This part doesn't require calculation or formula application. It simply follows directly from theorem statement above.<|end_of_document|>

0.user_question:
Find all the integer roots of
\[x^4 + 5x^3 + 9x^2 - x - 14 = 0.\]Enter all the integer roots, separated by commas.

direct_answer.text: Let's look for rational roots using the Rational Root Theorem. According to the theorem, any potential root would be a fraction whose numerator divides -14 and denominator divides 1; i.e., it could possibly take one of the following forms:$±\{-\frac{b}{a}, -\frac{c}{d},\ldots\}$In our problem above, since coefficients don't share common factors other than unity ($gcd(1,\cdots,14)=1$), possible fractions reduced below simplest form taking signs into account include...$$\pm \{−1, −2, −7, −14, 1, 2, 7, 14\}$$We try each such value until finding those satisfying f($r$)=$0$, e.g.$$f(−1)\equiv (-1)^{4}+5(-1)^{3}+9(-1)^{2}-(-1)-14=-1+5+9+1-14=0$$So, as expected because polynomial function changes sign when passing through real zeroes....and thus giving us exactly once even degree negative constant term nonzero coefficient odd power leading terms having opposite sign characteristic property allowing exact determination without synthetic division

Condition 2: Look for solutions among integers only. \Question: Identify all integer root(s). Separate them with commas if necessary. **Answer** Let us assume \(r\) to be an integral solution. Then,\begin{align*} r&=-1,-2,-3,-4,-5\\ x&=1,\quad &2,\quad   3,\quad  4,\quad    5\\ P(-1)&=\boxed{-2},\qquad\text{discard}\\P(2)=8+\boxed{16}+36-\boxed{2}-14=44>0\\ P(3)=\boxed{81}+\boxed{135}+81-\boxed{3}-14=200>0\\ P(4) &=256+128+144-4-14=420 > 0\\P(5) &=\boxed{625}+\boxed{625}+225-\boxed{5}-14=1470>0\\ &\Rightarrow\;&\boxed{3,\;} &\text{(rejecting negative roots)}\end{align*}$$QED$$

0.user_question:
Find all the integer roots of
\[x^4 + 5x^3 + 9x^2 - x - 14 = 0.\]Enter all the integer roots, separated by commas.

ost_step.1: By Rational Root Theorem, any rational root of the polynomial equation $p(x)$, whose coefficients are integers, needs to be of form $\pm p/q$, where $p$ divides the constant term (-14 here) and $q$ divides the leading coefficient ($1$ here).

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. From the hint, possible candidates for roots come as \(\pm\) the same set {±1, ±2, ±7, ±14} divided by \(1\). Checking each candidate using synthetic division yields \[\begin{array}{|c c c|} \hline & 1 & 5 \\ \underline{-1} & 4 & -\infty\\ && & +\infty \\ \hline & 4 & 0 \end{array}\] so one solution is \(x=-1\) but it turns out not yielding other real roots since \[f(-2)=\underbrace{4}_{=\,0}\,-\,\underbrace{6}_{\neq\,0}\,\implies\,x=-2\,\text{is another real zero.} \] Henceforth considering $$f(x)=(x+2)(x+1)\left(x^{2}-6\right)$$ shows us no more zeros over reals while indeed having four distinct imaginary ones. Note however how quickly our search narrowed thanks to Vieta’s formulas; those say exactly what you get once you know just about half your work already! As desired therefore $$\boxed{-2,-1}$$ Thus concludes my
